events.target_title: Copied text is garbled (but displayed okay)
Assertion failed: (json_object_get_type(jso) == json_type_object), function json_object_object_add_ex, file json_object.c, line 476.
Assertion failed: (json_object_get_type(jso) == json_type_object), function json_object_object_add_ex, file json_object.c, line 476.

note.body:
I have rebuild the json-c library by blinding replacing all ocurrences of `json_object_get_type` to `own_json_object_get_type`:

```
radziecki> /usr/bin/objdump -T /usr/local/lib/libjson-c.so.4.0.0 |grep json_object_get_type
0000000000005240 g    DF .text	000000000000002d  Base        own_json_object_get_type
```

and then gimp continues to start and runs past the crash point. (It ends up with another crash - which is the one I was trying to debug originally).

It might be possible that this crash is possible only with debug builds (I was using FreeBSD ports `WITH_DEBUG` flag which sets `-g` amont others) - I guess otherwise those calls could have get optimized out by the compiler.

and it crashes with the same backtrace.

To reproduce the bug it is important to build `json-c` library without optimization:


```
radziecki> pwd
/usr/ports/devel/json-c
radziecki> make -V CFLAGS
-O2 -pipe  -fstack-protector-strong -fno-strict-aliasing 
radziecki> make -V CFLAGS WITH_DEBUG=yes
-pipe  -g -fstack-protector-strong -fno-strict-aliasing 
```

That means that the default CFLAGS on my system are

    -O2 -pipe  -fstack-protector-strong -fno-strict-aliasing 

A debug build (`WITH_DEBUG=yes`) does not have optmizations:

    -pipe  -g -fstack-protector-strong -fno-strict-aliasing

FreeBSD uses clang as the default compiler, I am using clang 8.0.1 that comes with the base FreeBSD system as of version 11.3

```
> cc -v
FreeBSD clang version 8.0.1 (tags/RELEASE_801/final 366581) (based on LLVM 8.0.1)
Target: x86_64-unknown-freebsd11.3
Thread model: posix
InstalledDir: /usr/bin
```

events.target_title: meta: Fix static build on Windows

note.body:
Sorry, I don't think that I'm the right person for this job as I'm not familiar at all with the internals of glib and not really familiar with glib in general

I stumbled over this as I'm part of Bincrafters. We maintain huge amounts of packages for the C/C++ package manager Conan. Last version we got to work with all configurations we are testing was 2.58.3. Having patches like this merged probably makes it a lot easier and actually fixes it for all consumers

The [vcpkg package manager](https://github.com/microsoft/vcpkg/tree/master/ports/glib) also applies patches to the glib build (not sure if they are worth upstreaming), but this is getting now off-topic...

events.target_title: gThumb hangs when some mount point is unavailable

note.body:
Gthumb should not scan all drives; what is the point of this?  It should just focus on the targeted directory.  And if there is a hang against a drive, there should be a dialog box showing up after a 1s delay stating which drive it is waiting for and allow the user to cancel, reverting then to the home directory.

BTW, in my case, the hang is not infinite.  It is just a long timeout.  The image eventually shows up.

Separate workspaces on multiple monitors

note.body:
This feature would be a large improvement for GNOME workstations with multiple monitor setups.

For example I would like to have an IRC client displayed on one monitor at all times, while the other 3 monitors can cycle together through workspaces (ex, one workspace has github, IDE, and terminals, another workspace has trello, calendar, and mail client, etc).

EDIT: For my use case, I found the following combinations of settings to achieve what I needed exactly:

1. Disabled `workspaces-only-on-primary`

2. With my IRC client as the active window, `alt + space` -> `Always on visible workspace`

Now I have the IRC client always visible on the leftmost monitor, where changing workspaces cycles the other 3 monitors as a group.

This doesn't address all use cases described above but it does achieve what I specifically was looking for and I hope some others will find it helpful as well.

GIMP crashing on Clipboard Operations (still?) - Lubuntu 19.04

note.body:
I've seen a number of similar-looking bugs on the tracker but this appears to be the most recent, so I'm replying with the suggestion that it be reopened.

Same approximate configuration as @MaxMatti here and same error message. GIMP 2.10.14. The crash happens about 80% of the time when pasting a medium-sized image to another program, both with and without xfce4-clipman running.

There's no segfault, just an emergency exit, so my backtrace is from a breakpoint on `exit()`. The crashdump file mentioned in the trace is not actually produced. Does this seem to point to a problem in gdk? I'm a bit too tired to grok it.
[backtrace.txt](/uploads/941aa06c6e33432273c5bb11d8f0a50f/backtrace.txt)

enhancement request for perspective transform tool

note.body:
I've been investigating the kind of distortion described in this feature request and believe that the best place to implement it would be in the GIMP perspective tool, possibly as a toggle option to switch between this and 'normal' perspective.

This specific distortion can be described mathematically, I've produced some test examples and some more explanation in this article: https://medium.com/@brunopostle/piranesis-perspective-trick-6bcd7a754da9

I have some (bad perl) code that was used to produce the tests, and can provide if necessary, but the mathematical principles are in the linked article.

Here is an example undistorted image:
![original](/uploads/e172c91c1ce8bed68937ec3d9816c710/original.png)

This is remapped using the new perspective remapping, I think that for most purposes this would be preferred to the 'correct' homography mapping that is currently used:
![piranesi](/uploads/09154ecfa2de54402e1543ad70e28193/piranesi.png)

This last image is remapped using the conventional GIMP homography perspective tool for comparison:
![correct](/uploads/1fc9ef2a4d07384ba20ed7451214c5f5/correct.png)

events.target_title: Ability to input 'scale' value directly instead of having to convert to percent
enhancement request for perspective transform tool

note.body:
There don't seem to be any nightly fedora builds (I've compiled GIMP from source in the past, so I'm aware that this isn't always straightforward, I'll see if I get a chance).

I'm keen to try any new perspective tool, but note that this enhancement request is for an 'artistic' perspective remapping (that is nonetheless definable mathematically, and has historic precedent) in addition to the existing homography perspective remapping.

events.target_title: Ability to input 'scale' value directly instead of having to convert to percent

note.body: Thanks @Jehan, I didn't realise entering arithmetic is possible, I'll use this in future.

events.target_title: Ability to input 'scale' value directly instead of having to convert to percent
Ability to input 'scale' value directly instead of having to convert to percent

note.body: Yes please close. I only wish this functionality was more discoverable, but I can think of at least two other applications that allow arithmetic in dialogs and they are not discoverable either.

events.target_title: enhancement request for perspective transform tool

note.body:
It isn't implemented in Hugin because it isn't a 'true' perspective. This is why I call it a 'trick', it looks like a perspective and in many ways it is more legible (which is why lots of painters use it), but it is really just a 2D distortion, hence it being a better fit with GIMP than Hugin.

My perl proof-of-concept doesn't use a matrix, it intersects lots of lines and measures distances for the forward transform, and the reverse transform just does a slow linear search using the forward transform - I'm only any good at horrible hacks, real coding is beyond me.

`gio open` opens all files and directories in web browser
`gio open` opens all files and directories in web browser
`gio open` opens all files and directories in web browser

note.body:
Sorry for not including more examples and making it clearer. The same thing happens with files as well. E.g. with application/pdf, application/json, text/x-python, etc, despite firefox not being the default or registered application.

The output of `gio mime x-scheme-handler/file` is:
```
Default application for “x-scheme-handler/file”: firefox.desktop
No registered applications
No recommended applications
```
It appears to have been set in `~/.config/mimeapps.list`, though I'm not sure what set it. I removed it and now everything works as expected. Thank you!

note.body:
The same applies apparently to several other keys... e.g. GNOME apparently doesn't allow the keypad cursor keys as hotkeys (but it does allow keypad pgup/down).
So it would be nice if all the keypad-keys would be allowed.

note.body: This is the ticket from Cinnamon https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon/issues/2344 with links to their commits that made using single <Super_L> or single <Menu> working... maybe something similar could be done for GNOME :-)

events.target_title: allow to use just <Super> in keybindings

note.body:
1) Well I didn't know what exactly in GNOME is responsible for this and figured it might be g-s-d, since in dconf it contained the respective settings.

2/3) Well as always people want to adjust their desktop to their very personal needs to give them the very best experience.
In may example I've always used to assign Super to "Launch Terminal" (which is simply what I need the most and where I want exactly one easily reachable key to get it done)... whereas for example I use <Menu> to launch e.g. Diodon or gpaste, to access the clipboard.
<Super> is just always reachable without moving the hand to much, and obviously not needing to do <Super>+something makes it even faster.

If there's no harm, why shouldn't people be allowed to change these things like Super_L or Ctrl... after all, that's just the point of configurable hotkeys at all... if this wouldn't make sense you could just set *all* hotkeys to static values.

Thanks,
Chris.

events.target_title: allow to use just <Super> in keybindings

note.body:
btw: It just came to my mind, that even average users, who want to have the overview as quickly reachable as their "main function", could benefit from allowing to manually assign just Super.

Most modern keyboards (at least on notebooks) have only <Super_L> on the left side and <Menu> on the right, but lack the <Super_R>.
A left-handed person might want to just swap the two, i.e. get the overview via the <Menu> button.

> We don't need to check anymore for pygtk, pycairo, nor do we need Python headers. Everything is now taken care of by GObject Introspection and we have nothing else to build GIMP-side.

events.target_title: Two USB disks of the same type is recognised only once

note.body:
I just want to add that I have the exact same issue.  I am using two identical USB SD card readers and they will only show up once in gnome-disk-utility while both will show up in the file manager.  Even if both SD cards are different brands and sizes say one is 64GB and the other is 32GB. I have tried this on a few different distros and get the exact same problem.  Seems it has to do with being the same internal name.  It would be nice that if it found the same name device to just add a number at the end or even prompt or something. That way I could still format it and do all the stuff I need to do.  
Right now, I have to put one of the SD cards into a different brand SD card reader to get it to show up in gnome-disk-utility or just use GParted. 

gnome-disk-utility 3.28.3
UDisks 2.7.6

note.body:
Related to this issue: the text colour for events is white on the dark theme, but the calendar theme colours can be really bright, leading to unreadable text.

The event text colour should be contrasted to the calendar theme colour so that it's always readable, even regardless of the window focus.

I also have 2 questions about libiconv and libintl.
1)How do I compile with libiconv when libiconv in specific location?
2)How do skip copy libintl.dylib when it be compiled as static?
thanks!
glib --- ``` meson.py --prefix=/Path/glib-2.63.3 --default-library=static --buildtype=release build ninja -C build ninja -C build install ``` vips --- ``` export PKG_CONFIG_PATH=/Path/glib-2.63.3/lib/pkgconfig:$PKG_CONFIG_PATH ./configure --prefix=/path/vpis-8.9.0 --enable-shared=no make ```

events.target_title: Undefined symbols when linking statically on macOS 10.11

note.body:
@jralls thanks for replying. about static library issue --- Is it possible using C instead of `gosxutils.m`? about libiconv --- I have compiled static libiconv at specific location(not at system /usr/lib, /usr/local).
does it provide arguments for custom libiconv at config time or compile time? about libintl
--- It it a current way for static library(..subprojects/proxy-libintl/meson.build)
change `install : true` to `install : false` ``` intl_shr = shared_library('intl', 'libintl.c', c_args: ['-DSTUB_ONLY'], install : false) ```

events.target_title: Undefined symbols when linking statically on macOS 10.11

note.body:
@jralls thanks 1)rewrite `NSSearchPathForDirectoriesInDomains` function using C? (How about linux)

2)`install:false`
the `ninja -C build install` will install `libintl.dylib` and `libintl.a`.
so, `install:false` will only copy `libintl.a` in installation time.
but, I'm no sure, does it work without copy `libintl.dylib`?

events.target_title: Undefined symbols when linking statically on macOS 10.11

note.body:

I got it, so only one way is making dynamic library. right?

events.target_title: Saving to PDF changes text's font and size

note.body:
Same problem here with Gimp 2.10.14. I use two installed free fonts (Bebas Neue & Raleway). Everything is setup fine in my Gimp project. Gimp finds the ttfs in c:\(user)\AppData\Roaming\GIMP\2.10\fonts. It won't find the Fonts in the c:\windows\fonts folder although they are installed.
On export to PDF both fonts are lost. Standard fonts like Comic Sans do work (just tested it). In the exported PDF everything is displayed with DejaVuSans. This is the only embedded font in the PDF file.

So I think (like Massimo already said) it's an issue with getting the fonts into the PDF.

Do you have any ideas how to accomplish this?

I tried Massimos font.conf walk-around for the PDF-Plugin but apparently I didn't figure it out correctly.

events.target_title: Saving to PDF changes text's font and size

note.body:
No, this would be my last resort, if at all. The printing company is asking for a PDF with the text being selectable, as they say to individually tune background and text to their print setup. Also they will create an ebook cover in b/w from the file, so being able to adjust the text is important.

I tested two other 100% free fonts (Allura and Amatic) and had the same results.

Then I right-clicked the fonts and chose not "Install" but "Install for all users" -** now it works!** 
Well: the fonts are in the PDF!
However: all the letter spacing is lost. :(

Maybe that helps with the bugfixing. If you have anything, pls let me know.

events.target_title: Split window
my_work:  Add new dbus messages in oVirt.js to handle SSO event

note.body:
Hi Florian,

Perhaps I can shed some light on this merge request. This patch helps improves
the user experience of gnome-shell within VMware Horizon environments.

Context around this patch:

VMware provides a VDI solution called VMware Horizon, which has a feature
set much like oVirt. 

Earlier last year, I was debugging a gnome-shell failure in an environment 
deployed using VMware Horizon. I was baffled for some time because gnome-shell 
presented bugs from old outdated versions of gnome-shell, 3.28.1, when the
packages installed were 3.28.4.

After examining how VMware Horizon was being installed, I found that it shipped
libgnome-shell.so compiled for several different major distros and several
different releases, and that they were overwriting distro provided libraries 
with this custom compiled gnome-shell library.

This custom library was based on 3.28.1, and I found the source of the old bugs.
Another side effect is that if the distro updates their gnome-shell package
for a security update, gnome-shell fails to start in Horizon and causes an
outage until you overwrite the distro provided package with the old custom
compiled package. Quite a headache.

After digging some more through the open source packages on VMware's website,
the only patches they had were to implement a SSO feature:
https://paste.ubuntu.com/p/HHmjr9rK2X/

If you compare the above patch with js/gdm/oVirt.js, the vmCred.js is a copy
of oVirt.js, just with different interfaces.

As you know, shipping a custom outdated libgnome-shell.so library is not going
to work in production, so we needed to find a different way.

VMware suggested the use of G_RESOURCE_OVERLAYS to replace js/gdm/oVirt.js, but
from a security prospective, G_RESOURCE_OVERLAYS was never meant for production
use.

So, I have been suggesting that VMware upstream their patch. Then VMware would
not have to ship custom libgnome-shell.so libraries, and distros can simply
backport the patch to supported releases, and the problem is solved.

It seems this merge request has been modified to adhere to oVirt's interface,
which is good, since it no longer implements a duplicated vmCred interface,

note.body:
Hi Florian,

Perhaps I can shed some light on this merge request. This patch helps improves
the user experience of gnome-shell within VMware Horizon environments.

Context around this patch:

VMware provides a VDI solution called VMware Horizon, which has a feature
set much like oVirt. 

Earlier last year, I was debugging a gnome-shell failure in an environment 
deployed using VMware Horizon. I was baffled for some time because gnome-shell 
presented bugs from old outdated versions of gnome-shell, 3.28.1, when the
packages installed were 3.28.4.

After examining how VMware Horizon was being installed, I found that it shipped
libgnome-shell.so compiled for several different major distros and several
different releases, and that they were overwriting distro provided libraries 
with this custom compiled gnome-shell library.

This custom library was based on 3.28.1, and I found the source of the old bugs.
Another side effect is that if the distro updates their gnome-shell package
for a security update, gnome-shell fails to start in Horizon and causes an
outage until you overwrite the distro provided package with the old custom
compiled package. Quite a headache.

After digging some more through the open source packages on VMware's website,
the only patches they had were to implement a SSO feature:
https://paste.ubuntu.com/p/HHmjr9rK2X/

If you compare the above patch with js/gdm/oVirt.js, the vmCred.js is a copy
of oVirt.js, just with different interfaces.

As you know, shipping a custom outdated libgnome-shell.so library is not going
to work in production, so we needed to find a different way.

VMware suggested the use of G_RESOURCE_OVERLAYS to replace js/gdm/oVirt.js, but
from a security prospective, G_RESOURCE_OVERLAYS was never meant for production
use.

So, I have been suggesting that VMware upstream their patch. Then VMware would
not have to ship custom libgnome-shell.so libraries, and distros can simply
backport the patch to supported releases, and the problem is solved.

It seems this merge request has been modified to adhere to oVirt's interface,
which is good, since it no longer implements a duplicated vmCred interface,
saving the need to include all the boilerplate required in the pastebin patch
I included previously.

So what this patch does:
This patch integrates VMwares SSO interface into the oVirt interface in a
(comparatively) non-offensive manner. 

Why is this patch useful / necessary:
This patch makes gnome-shell function inside VMware Horizon and work with the 
VMware Horizon agent. This also does it in a way that distro maintainers like,
and not have nightmares about at night.

Feel free to ask any more questions, and I will help out as much as I can to
bridge the gap between parties.

Thanks,
Matthew Ruffell.
Sustaining Engineer @ Canonical

note.body:
Hi Florian, and other gnome-shell maintainers,

Could we please get some initial feedback on yun341's revised commit?

Now, I'm fully expecting this to require a few more iterations before we get
this right, so some initial feedback on the following would be useful, so 
yun341 can keep working away at this:

- Is it okay for the VMware Horizon sso modifications to share the same file as
the oVirt sso interface, given that they share the exact same interface, and it
reduces boilerplate code, or should they be separated out into a new file?

I suppose a separated out patch would look something like the original:
https://paste.ubuntu.com/p/HHmjr9rK2X/

- If it is okay being in the same file, is there anything else that needs
changing, except things like swapping the order of the oVirt and VMware code so
that the oVirt code comes first, and slightly improving the commit message a 
little further?

Any feedback would be appreciated.

Thanks,
Matthew

events.target_title: Text functionality not available

note.body:
Ok, found I think. There was a similar problem in Fedora:

[No fonts available](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1744377)

The problem is in `fontconfig`. 

Here is the patch:

[fontconfig patch for gimp](https://src.fedoraproject.org/rpms/fontconfig/blob/master/f/fontconfig-fix-1744377.patch).

I have added the patch to my package and I can use the Text Tool now. 

So I think, I will be able to finish the packaging. Thank you for your help!

events.target_title: Creating new entry (no repeat) , and it duplicates to ALL previous months!!

note.body:
Hello, I am seeing similar behaviour in 3.34.2 on Ubuntu 19.10.

If I create a new event on the 1st of any month, it will be visible on 1st day of previous months:
![Screenshot_from_2020-01-09_20-19-42](/uploads/d7647a912370c30d74bfd251b326f4ae/Screenshot_from_2020-01-09_20-19-42.png)

![Screenshot_from_2020-01-09_20-20-12](/uploads/db970c5e3747f5c0524557b1621e6f55/Screenshot_from_2020-01-09_20-20-12.png)

If I create a 2 day event on the 1st day of the month, it is sometimes visible for *every day* of previous months:

![Screenshot_from_2020-01-09_20-21-38](/uploads/8b9617115b91ea3e4c50f5a7b56ae9a3/Screenshot_from_2020-01-09_20-21-38.png)
![Screenshot_from_2020-01-09_20-21-50](/uploads/5f02e5bfd341739b57219e1fa701e8e6/Screenshot_from_2020-01-09_20-21-50.png)

It seems to occur with both a Google Calendar from Online Accounts and the local calendar.

Please let me know if I can provide any other info :)

events.target_title: Showed menus under Wayland are partially out of screen

note.body:
This bug was filed against ChromeOS: https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=992856#c8

We did some investigations and the GTK applications are not sending zxdg_positioner.set_constraint_adjustment() for a subset of popups (e.g. the language menu bottom right corner of sublime). The default adjustment is "do not adjust" according to the wayland spec.

events.target_title: Showed menus under Wayland are partially out of screen

Cannot import images from other sources?

note.body:
***Follow what I changed at your own risk as I do not understand the command structure and I may have done something bad to my system with the alteration I made or that I am supposed to know to remove the [ ] etc. May be someone will confirm that the change I made is acceptable.***

Hi :)

Thank you for the temp work around.

I tried this command and received an error: 

> $ flatpak override org.gnome.Shotwell --filesystem=/mnt:ro [--user]
> error: Too many arguments
> 
> See 'flatpak override --help'

I checked the help file and removed the [ ] from around the --user and the command worked for me and I was then able to access attached drives.

events.target_title: Cannot import images from other sources?

note.body: Thank you for explanation/lesson for me :)

events.target_title: Please include error details when stating "There is a problem with the current build configuration"
Please include error details when stating "There is a problem with the current build configuration"

note.body:
Edit: as I was writing the message above, I accidentally clicked on one of the lines in the Runtime block of the config. It turns out they are not lines of information, but a list of checkable options! (But the checkmark moves when you click another line, so really they're radioboxes.) And no option was selected by default. I selected org.gnome.Sdk, and clicked the big button in the middle of the title bar, and the build worked.

This is what the configuration looks like with no runtime selected:

![gnome-builder-build-config](/uploads/30377d3ca3d013601b90e8c0cf68a2ff/gnome-builder-build-config.png)

Cannot read files with FTP mounted filesystem on Linux >= 5.4

note.body:
I can confirm this issue is happening to me as well, I first noticed when trying to edit files via Thunar (Open with Mousepad) and nothing happened. Same issue occurred trying to use emacs. Upon further inspection, the operation was actually crashing and generated a core dump. In certain apps (like Atom) it would just not open at all, Atom would show an error via it's console. However, file editing would work fine with Geany for some reason. This also had the same behavior when I tried it in Nautilus when trying to edit as well.

I originally started a thread over at XFCE.org before I was linked here, pointing this out to be a GVFS issue with Kernels >= 5.4. I am also on Arch Linux. Using any Kernel 5.3x or earlier, the issue does not occur.

"contents returned by g_mapped_file_get_contents seem invalid."

"Program terminated with signal SIGBUS, Bus error."

Crash dump and more info that may be of use from my XFCE posting:
[https://bugzilla.xfce.org/show_bug.cgi?id=16357](https://bugzilla.xfce.org/show_bug.cgi?id=16357)

[https://bugzilla.xfce.org/show_bug.cgi?id=16357](https://bugzilla.xfce.org/show_bug.cgi?id=16357)

events.target_title: tracker-miner-fs eating my CPU
tracker-miner-fs eating my CPU
tracker-miner-fs eating my CPU

note.body:
Thanks for your reply,

I think the miner should start when I am not using my CPU, like 1-10%. Still, when I work on many things, as you can see, it is trying to index them at the same time, I build pieces of stuff like nodeJS libraries or generated Android build.
I think it should wait and resume its job when the CPU not in load.
It has lesser priority, which means the CPU will execute that process less often (whenever it gets an opportunity).

`tracker daemon status`

![Screenshot_from_2020-01-12_16-42-14](/uploads/3b433787d34bc8f879a87ed07f68b956/Screenshot_from_2020-01-12_16-42-14.png)

`journalctl --reverse --lines=1000 GLIB_DOMAIN=Tracker`

[tracker.log](/uploads/63b2859e11c5f030c4e3df6ace3880d5/tracker.log)

`journalctl --lines=1000 GLIB_DOMAIN=Tracker`

[tracker.log](/uploads/de242c2b601e80dccdd5608356d60ba4/tracker.log)

I have tried to change some compositor setting (System Settings -> Display and Monitor -> Compositor) and color picker works fine in 2 cases:
- When rendering_backend == XRender
- When compositor disabled

I hope it will help to find the problem.

events.target_title: Multi-seat support broken in 3.34.1

note.body:
I upgraded Fedora 30 to Fedora 31. Both multiseat and VNC stopped working.

I have two seats: seat0 and seat1 on the same WS. When I boot up my WS two login screen appears.
I can log in at seat0 and open the gnome session. But when another user tries to log in at seat1, no password screen appeared and the first user session at seat0 terminates.

If there are no users logged in at the seats and some user tries to open a network VNC connection, he can see the GDM login screen and enter the password. But his graphical gnome session starts at seat0 instead of network VNC.

I think the basic idea of changes in 3.34 that any user can have only one graphical session contradicts to the current multiseat and VNC implementation.

In a multiseat environment (in Fedora 30, because it does not work in F31)

loginctl

SESSION  UID USER SEAT  TTY 

      3 1001 oleg seat0 tty2

     c1   42 gdm  seat0 tty1

     c2   42 gdm  seat1     

3 sessions listed.


When someone opens a VNC network connection a new gdm session appears:

loginctl

SESSION  UID USER SEAT  TTY 

      3 1001 oleg seat0 tty2

     c1   42 gdm  seat0 tty1

     c2   42 gdm  seat1     

     c3   42 gdm            

4 sessions listed.


And when the user logs in to VNC, the session of gdm disappears and the session of the new user appears:

loginctl

SESSION  UID USER    SEAT  TTY 

      3 1001 oleg    seat0 tty2

      5 1002 larissa           

     c1   42 gdm     seat0 tty1

     c2   42 gdm     seat1     

4 sessions listed.

events.target_title: Multi-seat support broken in 3.34.1

note.body:
This patch restored the correct multi-seat behavior for me: users can log in in all seats, lock screens and unlock them with their passwords.

[gdm-3.34.1-multiseat-1.patch](/uploads/b35791b50405767a03ee9d8444eb749a/gdm-3.34.1-multiseat-1.patch)

But VNC is still broken: when I connect to the greater screen and pick a user account, only the first char of password is accepted an the password enter dialog gets frozen.

events.target_title: Multi-seat support broken in 3.34.1

note.body: After more research I realised that the password dialog works with VNC and allows to enter a password, but does not visualize it: only the first 'asterisk' appear

events.target_title: Multi-seat support broken in 3.34.1

note.body:
>  It would help, if we first tried to use `sd_pid_get_session` and only did a fallback to user based lookup when that does not work.

Yes, It is a good idea. I implemented it in my patch above in gdm-manager.c: sometimes the sender is gdm with several sessions and the process-based session and seat is OK, but sometimes the sender is systemd-based, so we should use the user-based session and seat.

events.target_title: Multi-seat support broken in 3.34.1

note.body: After adding --builtin the user gnome desktop gets crached with "Something wrong".

note.body: After more research I realised that the password dialog works with VNC and allows to enter a password, but does not visualize it: only the first 'asterisk' appear

events.target_title: Multi-seat support broken in 3.34.1

note.body:
>  It would help, if we first tried to use `sd_pid_get_session` and only did a fallback to user based lookup when that does not work.

Yes, It is a good idea. I implemented it in my patch above in gdm-manager.c: sometimes the sender is gdm with several sessions and the process-based session and seat is OK, but sometimes the sender is systemd-based, so we should use the user-based session and seat.

events.target_title: Multi-seat support broken in 3.34.1

note.body: After adding --builtin the user gnome desktop gets crached with "Something wrong".

events.target_title: Multi-seat support broken in 3.34.1

note.body:
I upgraded Fedora 30 to Fedora 31. Both multiseat and VNC stopped working.

I have two seats: seat0 and seat1 on the same WS. When I boot up my WS two login screen appears.
I can log in at seat0 and open the gnome session. But when another user tries to log in at seat1, no password screen appeared and the first user session at seat0 terminates.

If there are no users logged in at the seats and some user tries to open a network VNC connection, he can see the GDM login screen and enter the password. But his graphical gnome session starts at seat0 instead of network VNC.

I think the basic idea of changes in 3.34 that any user can have only one graphical session contradicts to the current multiseat and VNC implementation.

In a multiseat environment (in Fedora 30, because it does not work in F31)

loginctl

SESSION  UID USER SEAT  TTY 

      3 1001 oleg seat0 tty2

     c1   42 gdm  seat0 tty1

     c2   42 gdm  seat1     

3 sessions listed.


When someone opens a VNC network connection a new gdm session appears:

loginctl

SESSION  UID USER SEAT  TTY 

      3 1001 oleg seat0 tty2

     c1   42 gdm  seat0 tty1

     c2   42 gdm  seat1     

     c3   42 gdm            

4 sessions listed.


And when the user logs in to VNC, the session of gdm disappears and the session of the new user appears:

loginctl

SESSION  UID USER    SEAT  TTY 

      3 1001 oleg    seat0 tty2

      5 1002 larissa           

     c1   42 gdm     seat0 tty1

     c2   42 gdm     seat1     

4 sessions listed.

events.target_title: Multi-seat support broken in 3.34.1

note.body:
This patch restored the correct multi-seat behavior for me: users can log in in all seats, lock screens and unlock them with their passwords.

[gdm-3.34.1-multiseat-1.patch](/uploads/b35791b50405767a03ee9d8444eb749a/gdm-3.34.1-multiseat-1.patch)

But VNC is still broken: when I connect to the greater screen and pick a user account, only the first char of password is accepted an the password enter dialog gets frozen.

GIMP 2.10.8 crashes on LUbuntu, the error was 'BadWindow (invalid Window parameter)'.
GIMP 2.10.8 crashes on LUbuntu, the error was 'BadWindow (invalid Window parameter)'.

note.body:
*  GIMP version: 2.10.8
*  Operating System: LUbuntu 19.04 (Linux)
*  Package: apt package
*  Other System infos: 
  *  Dual core 2Ghz, 3 GB RAM
  *  VGA compatible controller: Intel Corporation 82945G/GZ Integrated Graphics Controller (rev 02)
  *  Desktop on LUbuntu is LxQT/Openbox, and i'm running XCompmgr.

# Description of the bug
```
:~$ gimp-2.10 
gimp_color_transform_new: using babl for 'sRGB IEC61966-2.1' -> 'GIMP built-in sRGB'
gimp_color_transform_new: using babl for 'sRGB IEC61966-2.1' -> 'GIMP built-in sRGB'
void gimp_gegl_convert_color_profile(GeglBuffer*, const GeglRectangle*, GimpColorProfile*, GeglBuffer*, const GeglRectangle*, GimpColorProfile*, GimpColorRenderingIntent, gboolean, GimpProgress*): converting buffer took 0,7013 seconds
gimp_color_transform_new: using babl for 'sRGB IEC61966-2.1' -> 'GIMP built-in sRGB'
void gimp_gegl_convert_color_profile(GeglBuffer*, const GeglRectangle*, GimpColorProfile*, GeglBuffer*, const GeglRectangle*, GimpColorProfile*, GimpColorRenderingIntent, gboolean, GimpProgress*): converting buffer took 1,5797 seconds
The program 'gimp-2.10' received an X Window System error.
This probably reflects a bug in the program.
The error was 'BadWindow (invalid Window parameter)'.
  (Details: serial 230643 error_code 3 request_code 18 minor_code 0)
  (Note to programmers: normally, X errors are reported asynchronously;
   that is, you will receive the error a while after causing it.
   To debug your program, run it with the --sync command line
   option to change this behavior. You can then get a meaningful
   backtrace from your debugger if you break on the gdk_x_error() function.)

(script-fu:1839): LibGimpBase-WARNING **: 12:18:04.406: script-fu: gimp_wire_read(): error
```

# Reproduction
Load few images and doing simple copy or square selections and switch from
1 image to another, the application crash. Happens with only 2 images loaded sometimes,
quite often.

Is the bug reproducible? [Always / Randomly / Happened only once ]
Randomly, but happens quite often here.

Reproduction steps:

1. Load some pictures
2. Do some simple manipulations, copy/paste, square selections, move layers...
3. switch between loaded images

…

Expected result:
Don't crash.

Actual result:
Crash.

# Additional information

Nothing in /var/crash/.

I added some of the images i was using in the "attach file section",
Maybe the one that has a layer is usefull..., that's the only image with
layers i'm using, i tried several time with this setup, crash very often.

Also the Windows version 2.8.* on the same machine works perfectly with
thoses same files, doing the same manipulations, no crash.

If you have a backtrace for a crash or a warning, paste it here.


quite often.

Is the bug reproducible? [Always / Randomly / Happened only once ]
Randomly, but happens quite often here.

1. Load some pictures
2. Do some simple manipulations, copy/paste, square selections, move layers...
3. switch between loaded images

…

Don't crash.

Actual result:
Crash.

events.target_title: External subtitles do not work with LG Smart TV

note.body:
Hmmm...
Is there still no solution to this problem?

miniDLNA supports srt files so I don't have to implement something else, but... Ubuntu 19.10 has built-in DLNA/UPnP AV services offered by rygel package. It can be easily enabled via System Settings utility. It would be great to solve this problem because users would not have to install other software.

events.target_title: External subtitles do not work with LG Smart TV

note.body:
I build rygel from the most recent code on https://github.com/GNOME/rygel.
I can confirm that external subtitles (separate .srt files) now work on LG TV.
Thanks, great job Jens Georg!

events.target_title: Menus drop down problem, menu drops upwards into other screen with vertical screen arrangement and theme other than System

note.body:
Experiencing similar in Gimp 2.10.14 on Windows 10. In my case it only happens if Gimp is used on the lower monitor (primary display) of an extended monitor setup (2 monitors arranged vertically)

All menus drop down except for **Edit, View, Colors**

If I switch the theme to the System theme from within Preferences the issue disappears.

Will check to see if the same happens in Ubuntu and MacOS.

events.target_title: Menus drop down problem, menu drops upwards into other screen with vertical screen arrangement and theme other than System

note.body:
Correct the problem is not there if the screen arrangement is horizontal (see below - Light theme selected - Gimp on primary monitor).

The problem does not replicate itself in Ubuntu with the screens arranged vertically (have not as yet tried MacOS)

I find the menu unusable on the lower monitor - but it is not a great issue, as personally I prefer to use the System theme, in which case the menus all display perfectly!

![Gimp](/uploads/7999753cc432fd3beab67b27a2b6f906/Gimp.png)

Plug-in crashed: "file-jpeg.exe"

note.body: I have the exact same problem after installing the latest Gimp version on Win 10, it worked fine in all previous versions on Win 7. I thought the error was in the Swedish version (which I btw can't get rid of in any way in spite of uninstalling all files and starting anew several times). I can't edit a single pic without this error. Tried everything, removing, reinstalling, redownloading etc, etc. Hope this can be solved somehow, I miss my Gimp.

events.target_title: Plug-in crashed: "file-png.exe" (C:\Program Files\GIMP 2\lib\gimp\2.0\plug-ins\file-png\file-png.exe)

note.body:
I have the exact same problem. Tried everything (reinstalling, removing, redownloading latest stable version). It crashes when trying to save (export) to jpg. It also crashes with the same error message when I try to open an image.

Sound crackling with lollypop. Fine with other audio players
Sound crackling with lollypop. Fine with other audio players

note.body:
Equalizer is not enabled.

I've tried with ubuntu 19.10 and it plays fine with lollypop (version 1.1.4.16-4).
So I've built lollypop 1.1.4.16 on ArchLinux and the artifact is gone.

I will bissect between the releases first.

I've also tried different headphones, but I can still hear it.

The artifact is subtle, but I've made another friend listen to the sample and he was able to hear it on my computers. I've also tried different headphones. At least it's not my ears !

events.target_title: Sound crackling with lollypop. Fine with other audio players

note.body:
Unfortunately it's not fixed with current git master.

Do you wan't me to find the last good release by bissecting, or can you point me to a release you suspect ?

events.target_title: Sound crackling with lollypop. Fine with other audio players

note.body:
I'm pulling the source from https://gitlab.gnome.org/World/lollypop.git.

It works before 6a602eae (commit 3f646357). There is no artifact.

I can't make lollypop work with 6a602eae. I've got the following error :

`INFO] 2020-01-14 23:20:13 Player::_on_bus_error(): ../gst-plugins-base/ext/ogg/gstoggdemux.c(4961): gst_ogg_demux_loop (): /GstPlayBin:player/GstURIDecodeBin:uridecodebin0/GstDecodeBin:decodebin8/GstOggDemux:oggdemux10:
streaming stopped, reason not-linked (-1)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/site-packages/lollypop/player_bin.py", line 435, in _on_stream_about_to_finish
    App().albums.set_more_popular(self._current_track.album_id,
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/site-packages/lollypop/database_albums.py", line 394, in set_more_popular
    sql.execute("INSERT INTO albums_timed_popularity\
sqlite3.IntegrityError: NOT NULL constraint failed: albums_timed_popularity.album_id`

Version 1.2.6 (commit 96a81423) works but the artifact is here.

events.target_title: Sound crackling with lollypop. Fine with other audio players

note.body:
The 4 branches works.

I can't hear a difference between the 4. I don't even know if I am supposed to hear a difference. Note that I can't really blind test it because I know which player version I launch.

On a side note I've got a funny bug with these test versions. I start lollypop without any configuration (no .local/share/lollypop and dconf reset -f /org/gnome/Lollypop).
The first run creates the library, the second run deletes every item in it, the third updates the library again, the 4th deletes everything again, and so on.

events.target_title: Sound crackling with lollypop. Fine with other audio players

note.body:
It works fine with current master and replaygain disabled.
With the default setting for replaygain (Album), it doesn't work.

Note that I've done all the previous testing with the default value for replaygain.

What's the source of this bug ? I've find it odd that lollypop decodes differently than other players, even with equalizer disabled.

events.target_title: Sound crackling with lollypop. Fine with other audio players

note.body:
It doesn't work on current master with the default replaygain value.
It works if I disable replaygain.

I've checked on Quodlibet which also use python and gstreamer. It plays fine with replaygain enabled or disabled.

events.target_title: Sound crackling with lollypop. Fine with other audio players

note.body:
The no_rg_limiter patch fix the issue. It plays fine with replaygain enabled (Album or Track) or disabled.

It's strange it works fine on your computer. I've got a pretty standard Arch configuration and I can reproduce it on my laptop (Intel HDA) and on my desktop (Asus Xonar STX).

So it is a bug with gstreamer rglimiter plugin ? I've searched their bugtracker for similar bugs and I've found none right now.

note.body:
The 4 branches works.

I can't hear a difference between the 4. I don't even know if I am supposed to hear a difference. Note that I can't really blind test it because I know which player version I launch.

On a side note I've got a funny bug with these test versions. I start lollypop without any configuration (no .local/share/lollypop and dconf reset -f /org/gnome/Lollypop).
The first run creates the library, the second run deletes every item in it, the third updates the library again, the 4th deletes everything again, and so on.

events.target_title: Sound crackling with lollypop. Fine with other audio players

note.body:
It works fine with current master and replaygain disabled.
With the default setting for replaygain (Album), it doesn't work.

Note that I've done all the previous testing with the default value for replaygain.

What's the source of this bug ? I've find it odd that lollypop decodes differently than other players, even with equalizer disabled.

events.target_title: Sound crackling with lollypop. Fine with other audio players

note.body:
It doesn't work on current master with the default replaygain value.
It works if I disable replaygain.

I've checked on Quodlibet which also use python and gstreamer. It plays fine with replaygain enabled or disabled.

Equalizer is not enabled.

I will bissect between the releases first.

I've also tried different headphones, but I can still hear it.

The artifact is subtle, but I've made another friend listen to the sample and he was able to hear it on my computers. I've also tried different headphones. At least it's not my ears !

note.body:
I think you are right, I reset my GTK settings and everything appears to be working properly now.  Thanks for the suggestion that it may be a KDE and GTK issue rather than a lollypop one, and sorry for the spurious bug report.

For anyone else running into a similar issue on KDE Plasma, I reset my GTK-3 config by simply renaming `~/.config/gtk-3.0` to `~/.config/gtk-3.0.bak` and then I relaunched lollypop.

Tif files with multiple layers gets merged by default

note.body:
I'd like to offer a solution for future viewers even though this is 2 months old. I found this thread after having the same exact issue with Sketchbook and GIMP and Googling it, so someone else will too.

At least for Sketchbook, I figured out a solution. Similar software might have the same capability. 

Save the file as "*.psd". Saving as "Photoshop TIFF" does not work, nor does saving as "TIFF" (default). 

The photo shows the GIMP Import dialogue. "boxes.tif" is default TIFF, "boxes1.tif" is Photoshop TIFF. You can see that it detects 9 layers in the psd. ![layers](/uploads/e919f4ecf9f2680d3e63abd37c0d9f13/layers.PNG)

Add new blue based style. Thanks to Will Farrington.

note.body: line 34 has a name of neon_pink but the colour is a yellow. 'value="#ffdd00"' should probably have been 'value="#ff00dd"'

events.target_title: Add new blue based style. Thanks to Will Farrington.

note.body:
Jeffery and Christian

I'm happy to leave it to you to decide whether to change the name or the
colour.

For your interest. I've used the cobalt style for years but one annoying
aspect of it was/is html special characters, e.g. /“/, which I
found hard to read (maybe age related :-)). After a bit of investigating
I discovered these are displayed in the XML Style - /xml:entity/ which
was set to /#blue/. I changed it to /neon_pink/ and it showed up as
yellow. I decided the color value was wrong so created my own copy of
cobalt.xml and changed /neon_pink/ to /#ff00dd/ and /xml:entity/ to
/neon_pink.

/Kind regards

Angus
//

events.target_title: Add new blue based style. Thanks to Will Farrington.

note.body:
Jeffery and Christian

I'm happy to leave it to you to decide whether to change the name or the
colour.

For your interest. I've used the cobalt style for years but one annoying
aspect of it was/is html special characters, e.g. /“/, which I
found hard to read (maybe age related :-)). After a bit of investigating
I discovered these are displayed in the XML Style - /xml:entity/ which
was set to /#blue/. I changed it to /neon_pink/ and it showed up as
yellow. I decided the color value was wrong so created my own copy of
cobalt.xml and changed /neon_pink/ to /#ff00dd/ and /xml:entity/ to
/neon_pink.

/Kind regards

Angus
//

Copied text from rich text editors seems to be stored in the clipboard as a bitmap in X11

note.body: Merging !939 may result in a better default if text is available from the clipboard, but it will *not* resolve this issue. A clipboard manager should not suppress available types and offer a subset or request some "best type" and hand that over before a target application decided about the format it wants to paste.

events.target_title: Copied text from rich text editors seems to be stored in the clipboard as a bitmap in X11

note.body: If the clipboard manager is not transparent (i.e. offering all types the source application offers), it should not interfere with the clipboard at all as long as the source application is open and can be asked for the format the destination application wants. In the case of LibreOffice these can be internal formats a clipboard manager never will handle. If the source application exits, the clipboard manager should store and manage all formats the applications wants to store in the clipboard for further use by other applications. These must not be limited to text/plain or image/* offers.

events.target_title: Please add memory (M+, M-, Mr and Mc) functions....
Please add memory (M+, M-, Mr and Mc) functions....

note.body:
Hi Robert,

Thanks so much for the quick reply!

My use of the Memory function(s) is fairly simplistic: perform one calculation (say A / B), M+ the result, perform second calculation (say C x D), then multiply that result by MR.

Or to perform various multiple individual calcs, M+'ing (or M-'ing) the individual results to create a final answer, retrieve with a press of the MR button.

I guess that some of these things may be achieved via other methods (probably involving calc history and various additional mouse-clicks), but having individual buttons for these 4 functions makes number-crunching far simpler.

I've been having a look at other Linux calculator options, but the ones I found still had some drawbacks:

KCalc - probably one of the better ones, but the amount/size of required dependencies is a bit much (Linux Mint xfce 64-bit). It implements the M+/-/R/C functionality, pretty much in the exact way a physical calculator would.

galculator - Implements it in a slightly strange/non-intuitive way, as the 'buttons' don't seem to work as a real calc.

If it were possible to add the 4 buttons/features (M+, M-, MC and MR) in the same way as a physical calc, it would make things much more usable, for me and a few others - I've noticed that the lack of these functions is an issue for a number of others when looking at reviews/comments on other Linux calculator programs.

In regards to the questions you asked:

1: I guess the retention of the memory could be persistent, depending on a flag in preferences? One a physical calculator it typically is erase upon power-off, so this would be fine too.

2: #69 wouldn't really affect things (for me at least), since it's really the presence of the actually buttons (M+/-/R/C) that's required.

I understand that this may require a fair bit of additional programming and that you probably have a sizeable list of other features to implement, but it would be a nice addition to any future release. :-)

Once again, thanks for the reply!

Cheers,

Mike.

Daniel van Vugt (vanvugt)  
Hmm, maybe?... Can you reproduce the issue with any other Gnome Shell popovers?

Yes, I tested and I can reproduce the issue if I open any popovers, for example: keyboard language, calendar or activities.

Thanks for testing that. Please report the bug to upstream at:
https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/issues

SOURCE: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/gnome-shell/+bug/1859260

gfileutils: make g_file_set_contents() always fsync()

note.body: For your information. If a stronger guarantee is wanted that the file makes it to the disk, an additional sync should be added. [0002-flush-the-metadata-of-the-rename.patch](/uploads/4c3d5e0f1de846d5ff0876952efb6e5d/0002-flush-the-metadata-of-the-rename.patch)

events.target_title: g_file_set_contents() can fill target with NUL bytes if it did not previously exist

note.body:
For your info. If you want to have a more reliable g_file_set_contents() an additional sync is needed: [0002-flush-the-metadata-of-the-rename.patch](/uploads/3dee7919dc6ac8b487ada615294a2158/0002-flush-the-metadata-of-the-rename.patch)

Something weird seems to happen when uploading patches, since it seems to remove the commit log:
```
While rename does atomically rename, it doesn't provide durability. So
flush the directory so the meta-data is on the disk as well, before
reporting g_file_set_contents was successfull, so even in case of a
crash the new contents will be there.

For our use case: embedded product with ubifs, which doesn't have a
workaround for buggy applications [1] that behavior is wanted. For
e.g. connman stores the Wifi password etc with g_file_set_contents.
When power cycling the device after entering the Wifi settings, the
entered settings should be used directly. Not after an unknown amount
of time.

[1] http://www.linux-mtd.infradead.org/doc/ubifs.html#L_sync_exceptions
```

Unable to login to Riot.im or custom server from Fractal
Unable to login to Riot.im or custom server from Fractal

note.body:
Okay, here's an update.

I'm able to login to the Riot instance from Fractal by changing the provider url from `riot.im/app` to `matrix.org`. (That make sense, since matrix.org is the identity server and riot uses it). Figured it out by playing around. Custom server is still out of the question. Planning to try with a self hosted one.

With that being said, the following are worth doing.
1. Updated documentation
2. Server validation in the "Provider" page.

Closing this issue.

events.target_title: French translation update + ‘New file’ feature
French translation update + ‘New file’ feature

note.body:
When you have a program which takes data from small binary files, you can create such a file using GHex with the ‘New file’ feature and the insert mode. It will likely be for testing purposes or to create a data file for an arbitrary program.

It’s also a handy feature to test GHex and to nurture the idea that binary files can be created and manipulated like a familiar document (as many reverse-engineering works suggest) — :wink:.

Anyway it’s only a few lines of code.

I hope you’re okay with other changes (described in commit messages) too.

events.target_title: French translation update + ‘New file’ feature

note.body:
Is there a guide somewhere that says how to deal with translations in this project? I commonly update all the PO files with new strings when there are new ones or for each release, so that translators can just pick the file, write their translations and submit the result, but it seems it was not managed this way before. Some PO files have not been updated during many years, e.g. help/it/it.po in master is based on a template from 2007.

GHex’s help is actually quite outdated too. I should work on it.

events.target_title: French translation update + ‘New file’ feature
French translation update + ‘New file’ feature

note.body:
When you have a program which takes data from small binary files, you can create such a file using GHex with the ‘New file’ feature and the insert mode. It will likely be for testing purposes or to create a data file for an arbitrary program.

It’s also a handy feature to test GHex and to nurture the idea that binary files can be created and manipulated like a familiar document (as many reverse-engineering works suggest) — :wink:.

Anyway it’s only a few lines of code.

I hope you’re okay with other changes (described in commit messages) too.

==> Caveats
gettext is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides the BSD gettext library & some software gets confused if both are in the library path.

If you need to have gettext first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/gettext/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find gettext you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/gettext/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/gettext/include"

==> Caveats
icu4c is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides libicucore.dylib (but nothing else).

If you need to have icu4c first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/sbin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find icu4c you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/icu4c/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/icu4c/include"

For pkg-config to find icu4c you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/lib/pkgconfig"

==> Caveats
==> gettext
gettext is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides the BSD gettext library & some software gets confused if both are in the library path.

If you need to have gettext first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/gettext/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find gettext you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/gettext/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/gettext/include"

==> libffi
libffi is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because some formulae require a newer version of libffi.

For compilers to find libffi you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/libffi/lib"

For pkg-config to find libffi you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/libffi/lib/pkgconfig"

==> openssl@1.1
A CA file has been bootstrapped using certificates from the system
keychain. To add additional certificates, place .pem files in
  /usr/local/etc/openssl@1.1/certs

and run
  /usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/bin/c_rehash

openssl@1.1 is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because openssl/libressl is provided by macOS so don't link an incompatible version.

If you need to have openssl@1.1 first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find openssl@1.1 you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/include"

For pkg-config to find openssl@1.1 you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/lib/pkgconfig"

==> readline
readline is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides the BSD libedit library, which shadows libreadline.
In order to prevent conflicts when programs look for libreadline we are
defaulting this GNU Readline installation to keg-only.

For compilers to find readline you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/readline/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/readline/include"

For pkg-config to find readline you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/readline/lib/pkgconfig"

==> sqlite
sqlite is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides an older sqlite3.

If you need to have sqlite first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/sqlite/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find sqlite you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/sqlite/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/sqlite/include"

For pkg-config to find sqlite you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/sqlite/lib/pkgconfig"

==> python
Python has been installed as
  /usr/local/bin/python3

Unversioned symlinks `python`, `python-config`, `pip` etc. pointing to
`python3`, `python3-config`, `pip3` etc., respectively, have been installed into
  /usr/local/opt/python/libexec/bin

If you need Homebrew's Python 2.7 run
  brew install python@2

You can install Python packages with
  pip3 install <package>
They will install into the site-package directory
  /usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages

See: https://docs.brew.sh/Homebrew-and-Python
==> glib
Bash completion has been installed to:
  /usr/local/etc/bash_completion.d
==> icu4c
icu4c is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides libicucore.dylib (but nothing else).

If you need to have icu4c first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/sbin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find icu4c you may need to set:

because macOS provides libicucore.dylib (but nothing else).

If you need to have icu4c first in your PATH run:

For compilers to find icu4c you may need to set:

==> Caveats
==> gettext
gettext is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides the BSD gettext library & some software gets confused if both are in the library path.

If you need to have gettext first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/gettext/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find gettext you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/gettext/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/gettext/include"

==> libffi
libffi is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because some formulae require a newer version of libffi.

For compilers to find libffi you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/libffi/lib"

For pkg-config to find libffi you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/libffi/lib/pkgconfig"

==> openssl@1.1
A CA file has been bootstrapped using certificates from the system
keychain. To add additional certificates, place .pem files in
  /usr/local/etc/openssl@1.1/certs

and run
  /usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/bin/c_rehash

openssl@1.1 is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because openssl/libressl is provided by macOS so don't link an incompatible version.

If you need to have openssl@1.1 first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find openssl@1.1 you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/include"

For pkg-config to find openssl@1.1 you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/lib/pkgconfig"

==> readline
readline is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides the BSD libedit library, which shadows libreadline.
In order to prevent conflicts when programs look for libreadline we are
defaulting this GNU Readline installation to keg-only.

For compilers to find readline you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/readline/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/readline/include"

For pkg-config to find readline you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/readline/lib/pkgconfig"

==> sqlite
sqlite is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides an older sqlite3.

If you need to have sqlite first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/sqlite/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find sqlite you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/sqlite/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/sqlite/include"

For pkg-config to find sqlite you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/sqlite/lib/pkgconfig"

==> python
Python has been installed as
  /usr/local/bin/python3

Unversioned symlinks `python`, `python-config`, `pip` etc. pointing to
`python3`, `python3-config`, `pip3` etc., respectively, have been installed into

If you need Homebrew's Python 2.7 run

You can install Python packages with

They will install into the site-package directory

because openssl/libressl is provided by macOS so don't link an incompatible version.

If you need to have openssl@1.1 first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find openssl@1.1 you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/include"

For pkg-config to find openssl@1.1 you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/lib/pkgconfig"

==> readline
readline is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides the BSD libedit library, which shadows libreadline.
In order to prevent conflicts when programs look for libreadline we are
defaulting this GNU Readline installation to keg-only.

For compilers to find readline you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/readline/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/readline/include"

For pkg-config to find readline you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/readline/lib/pkgconfig"

==> sqlite
sqlite is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides an older sqlite3.

If you need to have sqlite first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/sqlite/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find sqlite you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/sqlite/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/sqlite/include"

For pkg-config to find sqlite you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/sqlite/lib/pkgconfig"

==> python
Python has been installed as
  /usr/local/bin/python3

Unversioned symlinks `python`, `python-config`, `pip` etc. pointing to
`python3`, `python3-config`, `pip3` etc., respectively, have been installed into
  /usr/local/opt/python/libexec/bin

If you need Homebrew's Python 2.7 run
  brew install python@2

You can install Python packages with
  pip3 install <package>
They will install into the site-package directory
  /usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages

See: https://docs.brew.sh/Homebrew-and-Python
==> glib
Bash completion has been installed to:
  /usr/local/etc/bash_completion.d
==> icu4c
icu4c is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides libicucore.dylib (but nothing else).

If you need to have icu4c first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/sbin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find icu4c you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/icu4c/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/icu4c/include"

For pkg-config to find icu4c you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/lib/pkgconfig"

==> gettext
gettext is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides the BSD gettext library & some software gets confused if both are in the library path.

If you need to have gettext first in your PATH run:

For compilers to find gettext you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/gettext/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/gettext/include"

==> libffi
libffi is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because some formulae require a newer version of libffi.

For compilers to find libffi you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/libffi/lib"

For pkg-config to find libffi you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/libffi/lib/pkgconfig"

keychain. To add additional certificates, place .pem files in

and run
  /usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/bin/c_rehash

openssl@1.1 is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because openssl/libressl is provided by macOS so don't link an incompatible version.

If you need to have openssl@1.1 first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

readline is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides the BSD libedit library, which shadows libreadline.

defaulting this GNU Readline installation to keg-only.

==> Caveats
icu4c is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides libicucore.dylib (but nothing else).

If you need to have icu4c first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/sbin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find icu4c you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/icu4c/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/icu4c/include"

For pkg-config to find icu4c you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/lib/pkgconfig"

==> Caveats
==> gettext
gettext is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides the BSD gettext library & some software gets confused if both are in the library path.

If you need to have gettext first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/gettext/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find gettext you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/gettext/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/gettext/include"

==> libffi
libffi is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because some formulae require a newer version of libffi.

For compilers to find libffi you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/libffi/lib"

For pkg-config to find libffi you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/libffi/lib/pkgconfig"

==> openssl@1.1
A CA file has been bootstrapped using certificates from the system
keychain. To add additional certificates, place .pem files in
  /usr/local/etc/openssl@1.1/certs

and run
  /usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/bin/c_rehash

openssl@1.1 is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because openssl/libressl is provided by macOS so don't link an incompatible version.

If you need to have openssl@1.1 first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find openssl@1.1 you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/include"

For pkg-config to find openssl@1.1 you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/lib/pkgconfig"

==> readline
readline is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides the BSD libedit library, which shadows libreadline.
In order to prevent conflicts when programs look for libreadline we are
defaulting this GNU Readline installation to keg-only.

For compilers to find readline you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/readline/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/readline/include"

For pkg-config to find readline you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/readline/lib/pkgconfig"

==> sqlite
sqlite is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides an older sqlite3.

If you need to have sqlite first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/sqlite/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find sqlite you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/sqlite/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/sqlite/include"

For pkg-config to find sqlite you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/sqlite/lib/pkgconfig"

==> python
Python has been installed as
  /usr/local/bin/python3

Unversioned symlinks `python`, `python-config`, `pip` etc. pointing to
`python3`, `python3-config`, `pip3` etc., respectively, have been installed into
  /usr/local/opt/python/libexec/bin

If you need Homebrew's Python 2.7 run
  brew install python@2

You can install Python packages with
  pip3 install <package>
They will install into the site-package directory
  /usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages

See: https://docs.brew.sh/Homebrew-and-Python

icu4c is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides libicucore.dylib (but nothing else).

If you need to have icu4c first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/sbin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find icu4c you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/icu4c/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/icu4c/include"

For pkg-config to find icu4c you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/lib/pkgconfig"

==> Caveats
==> gettext
gettext is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides the BSD gettext library & some software gets confused if both are in the library path.

If you need to have gettext first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/gettext/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find gettext you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/gettext/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/gettext/include"

==> libffi
libffi is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because some formulae require a newer version of libffi.

For compilers to find libffi you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/libffi/lib"

For pkg-config to find libffi you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/libffi/lib/pkgconfig"

==> openssl@1.1
A CA file has been bootstrapped using certificates from the system
keychain. To add additional certificates, place .pem files in
  /usr/local/etc/openssl@1.1/certs

and run
  /usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/bin/c_rehash

openssl@1.1 is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because openssl/libressl is provided by macOS so don't link an incompatible version.

If you need to have openssl@1.1 first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find openssl@1.1 you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/include"

For pkg-config to find openssl@1.1 you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/openssl@1.1/lib/pkgconfig"

==> readline
readline is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides the BSD libedit library, which shadows libreadline.
In order to prevent conflicts when programs look for libreadline we are
defaulting this GNU Readline installation to keg-only.

For compilers to find readline you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/readline/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/readline/include"

For pkg-config to find readline you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/readline/lib/pkgconfig"

==> sqlite
sqlite is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS provides an older sqlite3.

If you need to have sqlite first in your PATH run:

For compilers to find sqlite you may need to set:

  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/icu4c/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/icu4c/include"

For pkg-config to find icu4c you may need to set:
  export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="/usr/local/opt/icu4c/lib/pkgconfig"

Unnecessary Delays Recovering from Screen Lock

note.body:
I also have this issue.  Extremely annoying, literally takes over 60 seconds some times to recover from a locked screen.  The only workaround i have found is to disable screenlock.  Not the highest opwered machine, but this is the first time i have encountered this with gnome.
![2020-01-14_15_41_05-Window](/uploads/6517cc8ac38ed66395abb6c4cf2ff020/2020-01-14_15_41_05-Window.png)

events.target_title: Unnecessary Delays Recovering from Screen Lock

note.body:
I can set the monitor to 'blank' in the power options.

![image](/uploads/34f899372087a63f7e1d1f735ebcf652/image.png)

I agree that we need more control.  But i do think something is wrong with the screenlock function in some circumstances.  why does it take so long to recover?

events.target_title: Unnecessary Delays Recovering from Screen Lock

events.target_title: Sharing of Playlists using Rygel
Sharing of Playlists using Rygel

note.body:
Thanks for your reply. 
      My intent is to create playlists based on different criteria, such as; Beach, Christmas, Folk, etc.  I understand my library is currently exposed as a playlist of its own.  I have thousands of files. Using separate edited playlists to play subsections would be far more convenient in parsing this library from any particular client.  It's the sharing of these edited playlists that I am having issues with. 
I have been looking at rygel.conf and wondering if I can simply do something there to achieve this goal.

Thanks
Frank Mosuch


⁣Get BlueMail for Android ​

note.body:

Like [Issue 520](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/librsvg/issues/520).

events.target_title: Convert dot's svg output to pdf is incorrectly.

Use fastjar or jar instead of unzip when available (and warn if not for large files)
Use fastjar or jar instead of unzip when available (and warn if not for large files)

note.body:
I was trying to find out if I could make this PR myself but I got stuck looking through the source.

Here in fr-archive-libarchive.c we say that `_g_program_is_available("unzip", check_command)` is `false` then we add read to the capabilities...

https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/file-roller/blob/master/src/fr-archive-libarchive.c#L141

But then here we add read to the capabilities if that same expression is `true`: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/file-roller/blob/master/src/fr-command-zip.c#L423

I'm confused. I mean, the second one seems more logical to me, but yeah I don't get it.

Display scaling on HiDPI display causes poor animation performance on Intel graphics

note.body: What is the best way to test these changes and help in fixing them? Follow the jhbuild process for building mutter?

events.target_title: Display scaling on HiDPI display causes poor animation performance on Intel graphics

note.body: I was able to recreate your change locally from mutter!1004 and it seems to make a noticable difference, so that's good news. I still notice stuttering on the animation when you zoom into a workspace that you've clicked, but the initial overview opening is much smoother!

events.target_title: Display scaling on HiDPI display causes poor animation performance on Intel graphics

note.body: I forgot to add, that this also appears to be related to vsync. If I use a .drirc to disable vsync, the animations don't stutter, albeit with tearing. I wonder if there's some optimizations to be made with the handling of intel vsync and clutter/gnome-shell?

events.target_title: Add stand-alone password and passphrase generator functionality

note.body:
In my opinion, it should allow for password creation and show a strength meter like the password dialog in gnome user settings. This way, it would integrate best into gnome as potentially oposed to eff.

![image](/uploads/3764bd2ab1a11423c60ff76a7e9c197d/image.png)

However, I wonder how the length of the generated password could be configured.

NetworkManager-openvpn does not send client_hw_addr to server

note.body:
Hello, 

I was having a similar problem, it was because the Network Manager openvpn does not support push-peer-info, to solve the problem I created a patch and submitted to the debian bugs system  https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=948035.

The patch add support for the push-peer-info for the import, gui and the openvpn helper. Currently export will not work.

regards,
Peder.
